docs.snippet: We have many comedies about love but rather few about passion. We have many comedies about life but rather few about life-style. We have many comedies about language but rather few about its accentuation. Which is why, one supposes, Noel Coward's ...
docs.lead_paragraph: We have many comedies about love but rather few about passion. We have many comedies about life but rather few about life-style. We have many comedies about language but rather few about its accentuation. Which is why, one supposes, Noel Coward's "Private Lives" is not only so very durable but also so very remarkable. The fact that it is also screamingly funny has also probably never hindered it.

docs.snippet: lr by George Weil, former AEC reactor development div aide, replying to Carl Walske's recent lr urging expansion of nuclear power plants to conserve fossil fuel; disputes argument that consumers are saving because of nuclear power; holds that on c...
docs.abstract: lr by George Weil, former AEC reactor development div aide, replying to Carl Walske's recent lr urging expansion of nuclear power plants to conserve fossil fuel; disputes argument that consumers are saving because of nuclear power; holds that on contrary, nuclear program, particularly in its growth and small output stage, depends on fossil fuels and could, at worst, consume more energy than it produces; urges more energy flow studies; notes article by Dr Peter Chapman in New Scientist on studies and that Ford Foundation, in recent rept, was silent on subject

docs.lead_paragraph: A program that begins with Beethoven and ends with Schumann would seem to be pure gold. It did not hold true for the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in its concert in Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night, and part of the dross was the Beethoven work.

docs.snippet: PEOPLE As the lights fade on the current Off Broadway revival of Clifford Odets's "Awake and Sing," four things are apparent. Broadway's most eloquent spokesman of the Depression era never wrote a better play than this beautifully taciturn study o...
docs.lead_paragraph: PEOPLE As the lights fade on the current Off Broadway revival of Clifford Odets's "Awake and Sing," four things are apparent. Broadway's most eloquent spokesman of the Depression era never wrote a better play than this beautifully taciturn study of a middle-class Jewish family surmounting hard times and personal tensions.
